title: football-tutor-yellow-carded-general-teaching-council
story: A FORMER sports tutor at Borders College has been reprimanded after students were forced to retake assessments.Stephen McLeish was the course tutor for football at the Galashiels campus since it was created in .And many leading young players have passed through his courses on their way to full time contracts with clubs like Hibernian, Livingston and Dunfermline.But between  and  McLeish breached strict guidelines by allowing his students to undertake SQA assessments on publicly accessible websites.He also stored their completed assessments towards HNC Coaching and Developing Sport on insecure sites which were accessible to other students.The General Teaching Council for Scotlandthrew out a further charge of him providing excessive direction to students due to a lack of evidence.And the  also decided not to pursue allegations of failing to assess students work fairly and failing to provide feedback on grounds they fell within charges of competence rather than conduct.But they did uphold two charges of misconduct in relation to the use of the insecure website Edmodo.A spokesperson for the GTCS said: "The integrity of the SQA system relied upon the appropriate conduct of teachers in conducting the assessment process and required that teachers conduct themselves with the utmost integrity in their dealings with them."The conduct had been unfair to pupils as they had been required to retake assessments and called into question their integrity during the assessment process."The conduct fell short of the standards expected of a registered teacher."The GTCS Panel decided that a Reprimand should remain in place for one year.The spokesperson added: "The teacher had admitted the conduct and had reflected on it."The conduct was isolated and there was no history of misconduct."In view of the Panel, a reprimand was an appropriate sanction to mark the seriousness of the conduct in the circumstances."Mr McLeish hasnt worked at Borders College since .The College declined to comment on the outcome of the hearing.

title: damp-despair-galashiels-widower
story: A YEAR after reporting a roof leak to his housing association Gordon McLean is now suffering in his damp and mould-infested flat.And to rub salt into the wounds of the -year-old widower, the social landlord is about to bump up his rent and have even sent a threatening reminder for pound arrears.Mr McLean first reported problems with an external roof pipe at his Galashiels property almost a year ago on December .Further problems developed after a new bathroom suite was fitted at his Talisman Avenue home during the summer.And it was only when wallpaper began peeling off his walls that action was finally taken to stop the dampness.Despite being issued with a dehumidier the former gamekeepers property is still damp and mould can be found in several rooms.Mr Mclean told us: "I first noticed water leaking off the roof and an outside pipe and coming into the walls."The water had to be coming into the walls, but the workmen didnt think there was anything wrong."They did repairs to my taps inside but they wouldnt believe me that there was a problem with water getting into the walls."After the new bathroom was fitted the dampness smell became more noticeable, and within a few weeks my wallpaper began falling off."After I lost my we two years ago I took a real pride in my flat and decorated every room."I had the place beautul, but look at it now."Theres mould growing through the carpets, mould on the walls, the wallpaper has come off - how is someone meant to live in a house like this "Electrical testing on the property also showed that several sockets were dangerous due to the encroaching dampness.And Mr Mclean has also developed a bad cough over the past few months.But the biggest blow for him has been SBHAs decision to increase his rent and also send out a warning letter.He added: "While this was going on I went to a meeting with SBHA and they announced my rent would be going up from pound to almost pound per week - who would pay pound a week to live like this "I just received another letter from them to sayI dont pay pound rent arrears as well they will take court action."My home has been ruined by them not repairing a leak and this how they treat me."Scottish Borders Housing Association deny that dampness issues were reported by Mr Mclean before October.But they admit they were called to his Talisman Avenue flat last December, and also carried out repairs to taps earlier in the year.A spokeswoman told us: "In December  an inspection was carried out by SBHA with no further action at that time."Repairs relating to an immersion heater and also taps had been carried out in the property earlier in  and dampness issues were not raised on these occasions."The tenant contacted us on October  and a job line was raised including a specialist survey commissioned to investigate the cause of the problem, prior to instruction of appropriate works."Remedial works are currently on site following investigations regarding water ingress."The Selkirk-based housing association has also defended its planned rent increases.The spokeswoman added: "In November , we carried out a consultation on the proposed rent levels for the following year, giving all , tenants the opportunity to provide feedback, via a wide iety of consultation methods, including paper survey, community roadshows and telephone surveys."We advise tenants of these opportunities via their autumn newsletter, website and Facebook. SBHA has one of the lowest rents in the Borders and is committed to providing affordable homes."

title: extra-seats-promised-borders-railway-next-week
story: RAIL bosses have promised to increase the number of seats on the Borders Railway, from next week.A further , will be added on the Tweedbank to Edinburgh line each day from next Sunday.Just seven services between Monday and Friday will run with two carriages, as opposed to the current .And as part of the improvements, the .am and .am trains from Tweedbank will now have six coaches, rather than three.The changes come as part of a new timetable introduced by ScotRail, which also includes opening a new station in Glasgow.David Simpson, the companys operations director, said: "The improvements we are making to our timetable from December will deliver even more benefits for our customers, delivering more seats, more services, and a new station in the north east of Glasgow."The pound million investment in new and upgraded trains and the infrastructure improvements across the country are all part of building the best railway Scotland has ever had."

title: stobo-raises-2-700-charity-cocktail-sales
story: THIRSTY guests at Stobo did their bit for charity last month ndash just through drinking cocktails.The Peeblesshire venue decided to donate all proceeds from its new drink Pink Rhapsody to the Borders Macmillan Centre.And a total of pound, was raised.Mandy Winyard, director of Stobo Castle: "When the idea was suggested by members of the team, we were more than happy to agree and help a charity close to all our hearts."I would like to thank every one of our loyal guests who purchased a Pink Rhapsody last month, helping to reach this amazing total."A cheque was presented to the charity at Stobo earlier this week,Lynda Taylor, Macmillan nurse consultant and lead clinician in cancer, said: "We want to extend our sincere thanks to the staff at Stobo Castle and, of course, their guests who have helped raise such a fantastic amount of money to help local cancer services here at the Borders General Hospital."We really do appreciate every penny."Donations like these help us do things we wouldnrsquot be able to with our core budget and its these little extras and enhancements that really can make the world of dference to people who are receiving cancer treatment."

title: sevens-event-effectively-closing-off-melrose
story: COMMUNITY leaders have hit out at plans to shut Melrose High Street over Easter weekend.A stretch near the Greenyards will be closed all day during the Saturday and Sunday for the annual sevens tournament.There will also be a two-week closure on St Maryrsquos Road, where a stand will be erected for the event.And traders are worried it will affect footfall at one of their busiest times of the year.Martin Baird, who is a butcher in the town, told the recent meeting of Melrose Community Council: ldquoI am in favour of holding the sevens tournament, it is just a shame that the High Street will be closed over Easter Weekend. This High Street needs all the help it can get.Community councillor Graham Barker agreed, adding: ldquoThese are quite y road closures.ldquoClosing off the High Street is effectively closing off the town.For the first time, the annual tournament will be run over four days.At last Wednesdayrsquos meeting, concerns were also raised about people getting access to the Parish Church on Easter Sunday.But bosses at the local club say they are doing their best to minimise disruption.Alan Wilkinson, operations manager at Melrose Rugby, said: ldquoWe havenrsquot considered parking at the Parish Church yet, but we will take that away and come up with a plan.ldquoThere are lots of discussions to be had with the council and safety must come first.ldquoThe High Street will be closed in the usual place, but this year it will be closed from Saturday morning until Sunday evening.ldquoHowever residents will still be able to get access.A packed programme of events is being planned.And it will all kick off on Thursday, April , with the lsquoA Question of Rugbyrsquo quiz.An under s competition will take place on the Friday and a nightclub will be set up in a marquee in Gibson Park.The senior matches will be held over the Saturday and Sunday and the competition will finish with a concert. Mr Wilkinson said: ldquoIt will be an ambitious four-day event this year, because our ultimate aim is to attract the World Rugby Sevens in .ldquoWe are expecting , to , people on the Saturday and up to , for the nightclub event.ldquoWe also think there will be around , people at the concert on the Sunday.ldquoThe concert will be finished in time for people to get the last train from Tweedbank.ldquoHowever, we are hoping people will stay in the town longer when they come here. That will help local businesses.

title: online-self-help-guide-asksara-launches-borders
story: A FREE, online self-help guide has been launched by the Health and Social Care Partnership to help people find products and solutions which enable people to stay at home for longer.AskSARA is an online resource to help people live le to the highest standard by improving their quality of le by making skills such as cooking, bathing and taking medication, easier.This can be provided through mobility equipment or products which encourage independence.AskSARA is a  hour service and is open to family members, carers and friends, as well as service users.In partnership with the Disabled Living Foundation to provide the Borders AskSARA programme, the first of its kind in Scotland.To use the service, people have to choose between three options - health, home or daily activities - and answer some questions to receive a report from an occupational therapist who will offer recommendations for advice and support.If any concerns are raised in the report, AskSARA will suggest an occupational therapy session through a What Matters Hub.Developers say that AskSARA has the capability to improve capacity in the community for those who access health and social care services to better manage their conditions and support those who care for them.AskSARA also have the opportunity to improve the overall health of the population and reduce the number of hospital admissions.Councillor Tom Weatherston, Executive Member for Adult Social Care, said: ldquoPeople are increasingly willing and able to exert more choice and control over the things that will make a dference to their lives but with so much information available online, it can be dficult to know what can be trusted."AskSARA is an award-winning, tested resource that provides expert advice and information on products and equipment that can help you, or someone you care about, with your health, your home or your daily activities.ldquoWith access to over , daily living products from more almost , trusted suppliers, it has the potential to be of signicant help to people and I would encourage anyone who thinks they may benefit to go through the self-assessment process and take advantage of the personalised guidance that AskSARA provides.ldquoWe also hope that carers will find AskSARA useful by helping to identy suitable equipment for the people they care for. If they are looking for support for themselves in their caring role, there is a wide range of information and advice available from the Borders Carers Centre and they shouldnrsquot hesitate to contact them.To access AskSARA, visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk asksaraFor any queries regarding an AskSARA report or for more information, visit your local What Matters Hub, which can be found via www.scotborders.gov.uk whatmattershubs or call the Customer Advice and Support Services line on   .

title: focus-gala-camera-club
story: In his latest monthly column, Gala Camera Clubrsquos Ford Renton lts the lens cap to reveal some tricks of the trade.Its December now and, as most of the country are battening down the hatches, we keen photographers are getting their thermies ready for sorties outside to shoot winter scenes.The first pieces of kit before you even think about cameras are proper winter outdoor clothing. Plenty of layers, with a good waterproof top layer. Good thermal socks too as you may find yourself standing around for ages on the spot waiting for suitable light to shoot a scene.If you are comfortable then yoursquoll be thinking about photography and not about getting home to a warm fire. Thatrsquos protection for you, but you have to think about your equipment too.Top-end cameras have good weather sealing these days but it may not be  per cent effective, so get a rain cover for your camera bag and a cover for your camera. You can easily make a camera cover from plastic bags and rubber bands, and yoursquore recycling into the bargain.Another thing to think about is batteries, take at least one spare with you and keep it your pocket, not the camera bag. When itrsquos really cold the batteries donrsquot last very long at all so keeping them a bit warmer than ambient maintains their charge until you need it.Snow scenes make great subjects to photograph, and extremely popular. They are one of my favourite genres, running a close second to pictures of the night sky.There is a big problem with snow scenes however and that is SNOW. In a lot of hurriedly taken snow scenes, the snow will appear blue or grey. Thats not the cameras fault, its exposure meter doing what it was designed to do and try and get a compromise exposure to fit the whole frame. However, the camera tries to base everything on what we call an  per cent grey and averages the exposure to suit. Snow is very reflective, particularly in sunlight, and fools the camera meter into under-exposing the scene hence everything will appear dull and not like the lovely glistening snow you were looking at.This is where the photographer has to intervene. We deliberately over-expose what the camera meter is telling us by at least one stop, probably two. It ies a little between cameras and personal preference. I like to over-expose by one and a half stops. Stop! Whatrsquos a stop  A stop is the doubling or halving of the amount of light reaching your sensor . For example,the camera meter says expose for  th of a second, one stop over-exposed would be  th of a second and two stops over would be  th of a second. Using this method you compensate for the light meter wanting to under-expose.On your camera, you can achieve this by either using full manual control of your exposure or using an exposure compensation setting, which many cameras have. Et voila, nice white snow every time. Be careful you donrsquot drop the shutter speed too low though, or you wont get sharp shots handheld, even with image stabilisation . I try to avoid going below  th handheld, faster than that sometimes, depending on how much coffee Ive had.Irsquom not going to be popular for saying this but I hope we get Beast from the East . I had a couple of the best days out with a camera Irsquove had in years during and after that storm.Herersquos a couple of shots I took before sunrise two days before The Beast struck proper. The sunrise one is two exposures blended, one for the sky and one for the snow. If Irsquod just exposed to get the snow right Irsquod have blown out the sky. If Irsquod exposed for the sky the snow would have been dark grey. Sometimes you have to resort to a few tricks.Photo of the month this time is Festival Salute by our syllabus secretary Alistair Peacock. It is a multi-award-winning image this one, and one my favourites. Taken in Edinburgh around Tattoo time, Alistair asked this US soldierhe could take a photo of him. He obliged by standing to attention and snapping a salute, what a bonus. Perfectly exposed and works well in monochrome, great shot Alistair. You can see more of our club members images on our website on the galleries page, link on our home page. http:www.galacameraclub members-galleries-and-websites

title: pet-week
story: This weeks Pet of the Week, from Borders Pet Rescue, features Darcy, Snowflake, Meme, Junior and Ninja.The charity told us: "All five are between the ages of five and nine years and they have all come into our care through no fault of their own. We are ideally looking for them to be adopted together as they are used to living with each other."All five are used to living with other cats, dogs and children so are able go to a home with these again. Poor Snowflake is deaf, so whoever takes them on needs to understand this. They are all used to getting outside and this is a must in their new home."If you are able to offer these five the home that they need please head to our website to fill out an application form, www.borderspetrescue.org."

title: musk-says-faith-humanity-restored-cleared-defaming-british-caver
story: Elon Musk said ldquomy faith in humanity is restored after a jury took less than an hour to rule he was not liable in a defamation case involving a British cave explorer.The Tesla co-founder went on trial after calling Vernon Unsworth ldquopedo guy and ldquosusin a Twitter spat following the July  Thai cave rescue.A federal court in Calornia heard Mr Unsworthwas left feeling ldquohumiliated, ashamed, dirtied by the tweet from the billionaire.----Lawyers on behalf of Mr Musk argued it was no more than a playground insult and did not represent an allegation of paedophilia.A jury deliberated for less than an hour before agreeing with Mr Musk.Speaking minutes after the verdict was announced, a jubilant Mr Musk said:ldquoMy faith in humanity is restored.--vw,vw,px, px"Tesla boss Elon Musk, second from right, has been cleared of defaming a British rescue er --A despondent Mr Unsworth was accompanied by members of his legal team as he gave his reaction to the juryrsquos decision andsaid he would ldquotake it on the chin.Speaking to reporters outside the courtroom, he said: ldquoI respect the juryrsquos decision. Irsquod just like to say my legal team have been absolutely awesome. I came here for a verdict, unfortunately itrsquos not gone the way I expected but I respect the juryrsquos decision and thank them for that.Mark Stephens, Mr Unsworthrsquos UK lawyer, called Mr Musk a ldquobullying billionaire.He said: ldquoWe came here because Mr Musk said lsquosue or truersquo.We came here, we sued today, we sued this week and where we have got to is finally today Mr Spiro, with Mr Musk sitting at his side, admitted that the allegations he made were untrue.ldquoAnd it is a pity that a bullying billionaire has been able to cast such a long shadow and I just hope that nobody  has to go through and go toe-to-toe with Mr Musk again. Hersquos obviously put an enormous amount of resources into it.Lin Wood, the lawyer who represented Mr Unsworth throughout the trial, added: ldquoRegardless of the verdict, the message is loud and clear: It was a  allegation. But he had the courage to come to this country where Elon Musk lives and accept his challenge, he sued him. Itrsquos not true.Both Mr Unsworth and Mr Musk, who were seated opposite each other inside court on Friday, gave evidence during the four-day trial.Mr Unsworth, a -year-old financial adviser with a keen interest in caving, appeared emotional as he told of the impact Mr Muskrsquos July   tweet had on his le.Asked by his lawyer Lin Wood howhe felt after seeing what Mr Muskrsquos tweeted, he replied: ldquoIt feels very raw. I feel humiliated. Ashamed. Dirtied.ldquoFrom day one I was given a le sentence without parole. No responsible reader would conclude you were accused of a sexual act of a child.ldquoIt was a jape, Mr Spiro added..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Musk says faith in humanity restored as he is cleared of defaming British caver

title: approval-given-church-conversion

We were always looking for that space because we needed to put a ring in.The boxing club, which has a number of Scottish champions amongst its members, both male and female, trains on a Monday and Wednesday, -.pm, and a Friday, -.pm.Trips to New York to compete and train have been undertaken by the club, which has members from East Lothian, Midlothian and as far afield as Berwick.Anyone interested in finding out more or joining the boxing club should go along to any of the training sessions or contact the coaches via Facebook.ldquoNo one is turned away, said Mr McCallum.The other coaches ndash Tommy Quinn, who lives in Port Seton Richard Snaith, from Dunbar and Marc Skinner, a Tranent resident ndash are on hand to put boxers through their paces each week.ldquoWe are also very lucky we have good members of the committee and good parents who support the club, said Mr McCallum, whose son John is also a boxer.

title: cockenzie-family-return-italian-roots-open-food-lovers-paradise
story: They have restored the home of their ancestors in Picinisco in Lazio, Italy, and turned it into a holiday destination complete with a boutique hotel, cookery school and winery.Members of the Di Ciacca family moved to Cockenzie  years ago and Cesido Di Ciacca took over The Cockenzie Cafe, a cafe, fish  chip shop and ice-cream shop, in .The family lived above the shop on  High Street and integrated themselves into the community. Cesido was soon the honorary president of Cockenzie Star football club.The shop stayed in the family and closed in , just before Cesidorsquos son, Johnnie Di Ciacca, died.Johnniersquos own son, who is now  and is also called Cesido, lived in Cockenzie from his birth until he married his we Selina, , in . The couple continued to live in Scotland until  when they started their new business venture in Italy.The last of the Di Ciacca family to live in Picinisco died in  and their hamlet lsquoI Ciaccarsquo had been abandoned ever since.I Ciacca is a small hamlet near the town of Picinisco, Val Comino. The area is a historic region between Rome and Naples.I Ciacca has now been established as an lsquoAlbergo Dfusorsquo, which translates as a lsquoscattered hotelrsquo.Cesido and Selina moved to I Ciacca and began restoring the buildings ahead of opening their boutique hotel, Sotto Le Stelle, in .The same year, the Di Ciacca family started to clear the ground to plant vines at I Ciacca. A vineyard has now been re-cultivated and local farm produce revitalised, enabling the family to bring food, drink and authentic Italian hospitality back to Picinisco.The historic family buildings have also now been restored and turned into the cookery school, winery and further accommodation.This second and final phase of the I Ciacca project was completed in September this year. The hotel, cookery school and winery are now complete and taking bookings for overnight stays, cookery classes and winery vineyard tours.Cesidio Di Ciacca, said: ldquoOne hundred years since leaving to come to Scotland, wersquore immensely proud to be putting Picinisco, Val di Comino, back on the food loversrsquo map with the launch of I Ciacca.ldquoI Ciacca was home to generations of the Di Ciacca family for over  years. By breathing new le into our familyrsquos forgotten hamlet and the town, wersquore now able to offer a new generation of food and wine enthusiasts the chance to experience authentic Italian hospitality in an area of outstanding natural beauty.ldquoOur familyrsquos heritage of quality ice cream, food and hospitality since  in East Lothian is still to be found in Scotland today, including some of the best restaurants, cafes, delicatessens and wine merchants in Edinburgh.ldquoFrom I Ciacca we organise food and wine tours to learn about genuine local foods from pasta, pizza, cheese, prosciutto and other cured meats, to our own olive oil and letrsquos not forget wine ndash especially our very special Maturano.The Di Ciacca family is also working with one of the worldrsquos top winemakers, Alberto Antonini, to produce a new range of speciality organic wines made from their own Maturano grapes ndash a unique iety from Picinisco, almost lost and only recently brought back into commercial cultivation.The Di Ciacca family has just released its Nostalgia IGT Lazio Maturano in Scotland, which is the first time that Maturano wine will be commercially available in the country. It is now available to purchase from Edinburghrsquos Valvona  Crolla.Cesido, his we Selina, and son Giovanni, , now live in Picinisco for most of the year, but still spend time in Scotland. His daughter Sofia, , lives between Edinburgh and Picinisco.Cesidorsquos brother Paul and his cousins Marietta and Laura still live in Cockenzie whilst his sisters are Mary Contini, director of Valvona and Crolla Ltd in Edinburgh, and Carina Contini of Contini George Street, Cannonball Restaurant  Bar, and The Scottish Cafe  Restaurant at the Scottish National Gallery in Edinburgh.

title: plans-transport-hub-including-car-park-haddington
story: Following a series of closed door meetings, proposals by East Lothian Council for land next to Whittingehame Drive will be revealed to the public at a drop-in meeting in Haddington Town House on December , -pm.A proposal of applicationnotice for the site, which surrounds the townrsquos skate park and all-weather G sports pitches, was validated by the local authorityrsquos planning department last Wednesday.The simple drawings, which do not give any specic detail, show an area of land stretching from almost the gates at Haddington Golf Club in the south to the River Tyne in the north. The site borders the golf course and St Martinrsquos Cemetery.A formal planning application, which should set out exactly what is planned, is yet to be submitted.The local authority says it wants to create a ldquotransport hub with associated parking spaces and ldquobus connections, bike hire opportunities and new pathways.If approved, this would, says the council, have ldquothe potential to free up parking spaces in the town centre for short-stay use, making it easier for people to access local businesses, essential services and tourist attractions.Work on the project,approved, could begin as early as April next year. The car park would have somewhere between  and  spaces, the Courier has learnt.But some community figures in Haddington have accused the council of keeping people in the dark over the project.Liz McDougall, chairwoman of the Nungate Gala, said: ldquoMy thoughts are it is such a bad move.ldquoIt is going to endanger kidsrsquo lives and I cannot see the relevance in putting the car park down there.ldquoThey would be much better putting it on the other side of the town where they are throwing up houses and a school [at Letham Mains].Mrs McDougall questioned why the early plans had been made public last Wednesday ndash the day after the townrsquos community council meeting ndash when they were listed as being published the day beforehand on the local authorityrsquos planning site.She encouraged as many members of the public as possible to go to the drop-in meeting.Mrs McDougall said: ldquoI will do everything in my power andthat means trawling through the Nungate to get people to sign a petition against it I will."This should not be done.Pat Lemmon, from the townrsquos community council, felt there were a number of questions yet to be answered.She said: ldquoI find it very hard that the plans came in the day after the community council meeting. The timing was bad.The Whittingehame Drive plans come as early-stage proposals have been mooted for a complete revamp of parking in the centre of Haddington, which, as previously reported by the Courier, could see the long-stay car park at the townrsquos Tesco be made short-stay and the loss of up to  parking spaces on High Street and Market Street, a prospect which has concerned some town traders.The Courier submitted a number of written questions to East Lothian Council about the transport hub plans, including whether there would be a charge to use the car park and shuttle buses to the town centre what the projectrsquos cost would be and how it would be funded.The council responded that ldquowork on developing the proposals is still ongoing, adding: ldquoWe will set out more detailed plans in the months ahead, when such information is available.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe local community in Haddington first put forward their ideas in their lsquoVision for Haddington Town Centrersquo back in  and East Lothian Council has been supporting them in delivering their aims which includes lsquoimproving the attractiveness, ality and accessibility of the town in support of the community and local businessesrsquo.ldquoWorking closely with local groups, East Lothian Councilrsquos priorities are to protect and enhance the local environment while supporting the local economy, including town centre retailers and other businesses."The plans are ambitious and seek to create a transport hub with associated parking spaces that addresses climate change through the inclusion of EV chargepoints, bus connections, bike hire opportunities and new pathways."This has the potential to free-up parking spaces in the town centre for short-stay use, making it easier for people to access local businesses, essential services, and tourist attractions during the day."To help develop these proposals the council has secured signicant funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Town Centre Fund and has also made an application to the European Regional Development Fund.ldquoA public exhibition, where initial plans can be viewed, is expected to be held before Christmas."Comments received will help to form a full planning application and so itrsquos too early to provide further details at this stage but East Lothian Council remains committed to continuing our engagement with local stakeholders on this initiative and setting out more detailed plans in the months ahead.

title: married-woman-claimed-single-pocket-60-000-benefits
story: Claire Robertson obtained pound, in tax credits from  to  after she informed the authorities she was living at home as a single woman.Robertson, , began the wrongful claim in August  and carried on claiming cash she was not entitled to, under her maiden name of Wells, until March last year.But following an investigation, it emerged Robertson had married her husband in September  and he was earning an income.Robertson, of Dolphingstone View, appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday where she pleaded guilty to obtaining pound, in tax credits she was not entitled to.Prosecutor Heather Carmichael told the court that Robertson had ldquonot advised the tax credit office of her marriage and was claiming the cash as a single person.Ms Carmichael said: ldquoShe was residing with her husband and the tax credits should not have been paid on that basis. Her husbandrsquos income had not been taken into account.The fiscal added ldquothe matter came under investigation and the accused was arrested on March  last year.Police arrived at her home with a search warrant and she was taken to St Leonardrsquos Police Station in Edinburgh.Robertsonrsquos solicitor said his client ldquohad made provisions to pay the money back and stated she should be able to pay the money back to HMRC ldquoas soon as possible.The lawyer said Robertsonrsquos husband worked offshore and was ldquonot always at home.He added that Robertson was willing to remortgage the family property in a bid to pay the money back.Sherf Peter Braid deferred sentence until December  for background reports and a restriction of liberty assessment to be prepared.Robertson admitted wrongly obtaining tax credits amounting to pound, by claiming ndash between August ,  and March  last year ndash she was single with no other income when she was married and her husband was earning a salary.

story: Prestonpans Community Councillors invited Prentice Buses and East Coast Buses to a meeting last Tuesday to discuss the possibility of an express bus service at peak times.This followed a Scottish Transport Appraisal Guidancereport into public transport which highlighted that people living in Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton faced hour-long bus journeys to Edinburgh ndash yet those living . miles further away from the city centre in North Berwick could get a bus to the Capital in just  minutes.But Ian Bieniowski, network performance manager at East Coast Buses, said eventhe company could fill a bus at commuter times, those buses would not cover the running costs of the service.Ross Prentice, owner of Prentice Buses, also attended the meeting.Brian Weddell, community council chair, said: ldquoWe are being treated dferently from the people in North Berwick.ldquoItrsquos not right that you can get into Edinburgh quicker on a bus from North Berwick than Prestonpans.ldquoIrsquom sure you would get the patronage on an express bus at commuter times given the problems with the trains. People are looking for an alternative. Theyrsquore getting into their cars and traffic into Edinburgh is getting busier.Community councillor Gordon Laing said: ldquoI think that the service that we have down here is absolutely dreadful.ldquoWhat you forget with the  [bus] is Seton Sands and in the summertime buses are filled before they even get [to Prestonpans].But Mr Bieniowski said: ldquoEvenwe fill a bus with  people in the morning and  people in the evening, it still needs to cover running costs.ldquoWe do have buses that come out at peak times and then sit in the garage for the rest of the time but we have to minimise the amount of buses that do that. title: tims-tales-christmas-conscience
story: THE onset of winter, with the deadly cold and dark, was something John always dreaded.It was at this time he would make the decision to line up for a place for a hostel bed.John was homeless and he usually slept rough. Hersquod not always been homeless, of course, but people rarely see the person behind the label.The one good thing about winter for him was the approach of Christmas. Peoplersquos consciences seemed to be more sensitive at Christmas time.He was an alcoholic and he blamed himself every day for what he was. But this just fed his sense of worthlessness and kept the cycle going. His earlier le, the lsquonormal onersquo with his we and children, was now a long time ago, but when he slumbered he often re-entered it in his dreams.Especially that last family Christmas, when they were all together. He would re-run that time in his mind, just like his we would watch The Devil Wears Prada over and over and never tire of it. Yes, when he closed his eyes it could seem he was there again.But when he came to his senses, he came back to himself: an unloved man, old before his time, who people ignored and passed in the street without looking at. He usually felt completely invisible. To be fair, some people did stop and talk, usually the same ones.Perhaps they never truly understood just how valued those moments were.He understood it, after all he despised himself, so how could he expect others to feel dferently.Alcohol seemed to be his one real friend, the only one to understand and ease his pain.But St Andrewrsquos Day was approaching and this was his cue to get completely sober.He would feel that tingle inside that people call lsquofeeling Christmassyrsquo. It was a painful, bittersweet emotion for John, and his friend alcohol always offered to help. But he would close his eyes and be strong.It was the one thing in his le where he felt he had not let people down.So he would summon all his strength and draw on who he used to be for those last vestiges of self-belief and refuse the offer of help from his destructive friend.He made it and arrived at the door of the managerrsquos office, clean, sober and ready to work.The manager had no idea John was the same man he passed on a daily basis on the street outside.Admittedly, he did look dferent now, butthe manager had ever paused to look at John or speak to him, then he would surely recognise him. But for once he was glad of his invisibility. If the manager had ever recognised him outside then John would probably lose his job.ldquoYour costume is in the back room. You start in  minutes, said the manager.ldquoThe paperwork came through last week so yoursquore set to go.John knew the routine and got changed.When he sat in his chair, he was transformed. He was Santa.For the next five weeks, he knew he was going to be noticed and even loved. People would speak to him in a kind and almost reverent way, ask him how he was. His beard and red suit wiped away his sense of worthlessness.All that day, families came and he spoke to more people in that one day being Santa than he did the rest of the year being himself.Afterwards, he headed back to the hostel with money in his pocket.His old friend whispered in his ear: ldquoSpend it on me, spend it on me.ldquoMaybe later, but not now, John replied in his head.But the hostel was full and he couldnrsquot find any other place.And so he knew hersquod have to spend a bitter night on the streets.The food van would arrive soon, so he decided to wait for it in the busy centre.As he sat, a young girl came up to him.She just stood and stared. John recognised her.She had been one of the children in his grotto earlier and suddenly a fear gripped him: she might recognise who he really was.ldquoCome away from there, shouted her mother.But the girl still stood, staring at John. Then she smiled. John smiled back.Her father came up and took her by the hand, pulling her away without looking at John.He recognised the father as well.He had been so nice and friendly in the grotto, while his daughter stood with him for a photo.But without his white beard and red suit, John was invisible again.ldquoSpend it on me, spend on me, whispered his old friend again, as John had flashbacks of Afghanistan.ldquoSpend it on me and I will keep you company, nobody  cares, pleaded his friend.Then the girl was in front of him again, smiling.ldquoThis is for you, Merry Christmas when it comes.Her father stood by her, holding her hand, but still not looking at John.It was chocolate. The same chocolate bar shersquod chosen with glee in the grotto.ldquoThank you, said John and the girl left with her dad.Johnrsquos old friend was now silent. The food van arrived and he packed the chocolate under his jacket. It was more than chocolate.Now he had to get through the freezing night.Tomorrow, hersquod be loved again.

title: tims-tales-wise-old-witch
story: HAPPY St Andrewrsquos Day! The results of a poll on peoplersquos favourite Scots word by Scottish Book Trust was revealed this week.So herersquos a tale that includes all the top  favourite Scots words identied in the poll, plus some mair:THE weather matched the young wersquos mood: dreich.By the time she reached the witchrsquos cottage at the foothills of the Lammermuirs, she was soaked.ldquoOch, come in hen, ye look drookit, said the old woman sympathetically. They sat by the fire together.ldquoNoo how can I help ye  asked the old woman.The young we sighed.ldquoI just cannae thole it onymair, she said, getting upset.The old woman listened, waiting for the young woman to compose herself.ldquoItrsquos ma mither-in-law, she bides wi us and, weel, shersquos makin ma le a misery.ldquoHow sae  asked the old woman.ldquoI can dae naethin richt accordin tae her ma cookin is awfu, my hoose is mingin, I canne gie an opinion aboot onythin withoot her sayin the opposite, she treats me asIrsquom glaikit. Irsquom totally scunnerd wi it.ldquoI see, said the witch, ldquoand how can I help ye wi this ldquoI want her oot ma le, I want her deid.ldquoDeid  The witch seemed genuinely shocked.ldquoAye, deid, gone, awa. I just want her oot ma hoose and oot ma le.ldquoWeel, she doenae hae tae be deid fir that, suggested the witch.ldquoAye she does, I dinnae want her aroond. Shersquoll come knocking oan the door. Please can ye help me. I want her deid... er, wi oot it, ye ken, weel sae it isnae murder.ldquoBut it wud be murder ma dear.The young woman bent her head low and began to whisper assomeone might overhear their conversation.ldquoI ken, but ye are a witch, abody says ye hae potions fir onything. Please, I have siller. Mak it look natural. Then me an ma husband can get oan wi oor lives thegither.The witch thought for a moment, then nodded her head.ldquoVery weel, I will help ye, but ye maun dae whit I say.The we smiled with relief: ldquoThank ye.The old woman went ben the hoose to where she kept her herbs and ingredients. The young woman was curious and tried to sneak a look but the witch told her to stay by the fireside until she was finished.Then she came through holding a small bottle of potion.ldquoHere, she said to the we. ldquoThis will dae the trick. Ye maun put ane sma drap o this potion in yer mither-in-lawrsquos tea every day.ldquoBut she maks her ain tea, said the young woman, ldquoshe ay complains I cannae mak tea the proper way.ldquoWeel, ye maun find a way fir her tae allow ye tae mak her tea, said the witch. ldquoThen every day sit wi her as she drinks the tea. She maun drink it a.The we smiled: ldquoHow lang will it tak ldquoOch, mebbes twa months, ye maun use up the hale bottle. Then it will tak effect a few days ater the last drap has been drunk.ldquoTwa months!ldquoAye hen, it must be gradual, otherwise folk will suspect.The young woman clutched the bottle and nodded.ldquoNoo can I hae the siller, asked the witch, and the we willingly paid.ldquoMind tae gie the bottle a wee shoogle afore ye yaise it, the witch advised, ldquoand hud yer wheesht aboot this, or wersquoll baith hang.ldquoO course, said the young woman as she left the witchrsquos house.The weather had lted, as had her mood. Soon her problems would be over, she thought to herself.The witch watched her go, then closed the door. She had a knowing grin on her face.Two months later there was a desperate knocking on the old womanrsquos door. She looked out of the window and saw the young we standing just outwith the cottage, in a terrible state.So she opened her door.ldquoPlease, please help me, begged the young woman.The witch took her inside. The young woman had run all the way and her shawl had become wrapped round her hair, and her dress was dishevelled with the wind.ldquoOch hen, ye are in a richt fankle, sort yersel oot and sit by the fire fir a warm.The young we rearranged her clothes and started to greet as she spoke.ldquoHae ye got an antidote fir the potion please say ye huv, she said.ldquoAn antidote, hen ldquoAye, Irsquove changed ma mind. I gied ma mither-in-law a cup of tea wi the last drap o potion. I watched her drink and then she telt me that I mak a braw cup of tea and that she wis glad her son hud marrit me! It wis in that moment I realised I didnae want her deid!ldquoI see, said the witch. ldquoIrsquom afraid there is nae antidote fir the potion.The young women cradled her head in her hands. ldquoWhit huv I done, what huv I done, she cried to herself.ldquoYe huv got tae ken her, thatrsquos whit yersquove done, said the witch. ldquoAs ye spent time wi her making sure she drank her tea, ye will have talked, am I richt ldquoAye, sobbed the we, ldquoand she listened tae. I ken shersquos an auld witch sometime, er nae offence, but I understand her better noo.The witch smiled. ldquoGuid, she said, ldquonoo ye can gang hame and keep oan huvin the tea thegither, without the potion.ldquoBut shersquos goanie be deid in a few days, sobbed the we.ldquoNaw she isnae, replied the witch, ldquothe potion wis just a few herbs that wouldnae hairm even a wee beastie.ldquoWhat  Ye telt me that it would kill her! protested the we.ldquoNo I didnae, I said it would work ater twa months. And it has. It wis the hatred ye hud that needed kilt, no yer mither-in-law. And the same goes fir her.The young we was so relieved. For a moment she wondered about asking for her money back, but she realised the potion had indeed done its job.Her relationship with her mother-in-law was not always easy, but they had regular cups of tea and chats together, and often they would laugh as they shared memories and stories from le.ldquoThe claes are in a richt bumfle, said the mother-in-law the following day, then she smiled. ldquoBut letrsquos hae oor tea first and we can sort the claes thegither.The we thought to herself that the witch was indeed a wise woman.

title: community-kitchen-looks-raise-3-000-festive-raffle
story: Our Community Kitchen is looking to raise pound, through an lsquoOCKtasticrsquo Christmas raffle, with more than  prizes up for grabs.The fundraiser was launched at a special event earlier this which meets each Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in Haddington Bowling Club, said: ldquoOur Community Kitchen exists to reduce social isolation and loneliness for people of all ages and abilities in Haddington and the Lammermuir area.ldquoWe use food as a tool to bring people round the table to enjoy each otherrsquos company and make friends.Meals on offer range from sweet and sour chicken with rice followed by sticky toffee pudding, to pulled pork burgers and chips, with lemon puddle pudding for dessert.Miss Gale highlighted the grouprsquos strong links with the community.Earlier this year, the Walk with Scott Foundation, which was formed by Tranent fundraiser Scott Glynn, donated pound, after being impressed by his work.Miss Gale said: ldquoPeople are wanting to get involved and feel like it is their own.Last month, the group, which serves up a three-course meal for pound to an average of  people a week, secured pound, from The National Lottery Community Fund.The money is to be title: north-berwick-high-school-pupils-win-3-000-boost-good-cause
story: The pupils won their schoolrsquos Young Philanthropist Initiativecompetition, which saw them researching a social issue and delivering a presentation on it, with the best presentation receiving a pound, grant.The four pupils ndash Mairi Johnston, Jamila Sode-Woodhead, Kristina Grant and Emilee Large ndash donated their prize money to Muirfield Riding Therapy, where two of the group volunteer at a Friday childrenrsquos session.Their presentation was about the West Fenton-based charity, which offers horse riding therapy to children and adults with ious disabilities.Kristina said: ldquoThe highlight of the YPI course was the final round ndash winning the prize money for our charity made me feel very accomplished and as though I could make a real dference for the community and those who use the charity.ldquoI think schools should educate students more on disabilities and how they can help those who have them in everyday le. Businesses should also be encouraged to try and make their buildings and products more disability friendly.ldquoNot only would this help those with disabilities with shopping and other activities but it would increase their customer numbers.Duncan Binnie, religious, moral and philosophical studies teacher at the school and the schoolrsquos YPI lead teacher, said: ldquoThe YPI provides an excellent opportunity for pupils to engagewith their local community in a meaningful and constructive way.ldquoBy interactingdirectly with grassroots charities, pupils develop important communication skills as well as share information about the valuable work these organisations aredoing, often with little funding or resources.ldquoAs a school we have heard from last yearrsquos winners ,who are continuing to move from strength to strength and are very grateful for the pound, funding that last yearrsquos S winners managed to secure.ldquoMuirfield Riding Therapy is another example of a fantastic organisationcommitted to invaluable work within our community. To have a group of our own pupils campaign successfully within the school and to win important funding for them is a real credit to themselves and the school!ldquoA big well done to all the effort that has gone into this yearrsquos project across S and thanks to our  of judges: depute headteacher Robert Jones, our head boy and head girl, and Roy Symon from North Berwick Rotary Club.Susan Law, service co-ordinator at Muirfield Riding Therapy and coach at the session the girls volunteer at, said: ldquoItrsquos brilliant. We have had groups of children apply for YPI funding before but they have not been successful this time they have been.ldquoTwo of the group volunteers for us, they are committed and really work hard. They are passionate about the work we do and always go the extra mile.Most of the money will be spent on a new dementia cafe, with the rest invested in new hygienic toys and storage for the childrenrsquos session.

title: new-learning-hub-now-open-scottish-seabird-centre
story: The team have been working in partnership with Glasgow Science Centre for  months to transform all aspects of the five-star visitor experience and educational resources at the centre, which will reopen completely on Saturday  December followed by a formal launch in January.The learning hub will provide a more engaging and flexible space for inspiring and educating visiting schools, youth and further education groups.The new look learning hub and marine workshops are now available to book and it continues to be used by the charityrsquos weekly wildle watch groups, which are supported by the Scottish Wildle Trust.All of the furniture from the old education classroom has been given to Zero Waste Dunbar, a non-profit social enterprise which aims to keep good things in local circulation, rather than sending them to landfill.Launching the new hub, with young people from the centrersquos Wildle Watch Group, Provost, John McMillan said ldquoThe Scottish Seabird Centre has been a key part of East Lothianrsquos tourism and education offering for nearly  years. The new learning hub offers a high quality and flexible space that can be used by both East Lothian schools and residents, and those from further afield.Susan Davies, CEO of the Scottish Seabird Centre, added: ldquoScotlandrsquos marine environment is exceptional and erse. There is a growing awareness of both its importance and the pressures it is under ndash not least from the climate crisis, invasive non-native species, underwater noise and marine pollution. Our new learning hub will help us deliver on our purpose to inspire and educate people about Scotlandrsquos marine environment.Following the launch of the learning hub, the final space to be completed is the discovery experience, an interactive visitor experience which will enable people to learn more about Scotlandrsquos marine habitats and wildle, and use the interactive live cameras to watch seasonal wildle on the Firth of Forth islands. The formal launch in January will coincide with the start of Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters.

title: bay-city-rollers-star-saves-dog-stuck-hole-two-days
story: Bay City Rollers guitarist Stuart lsquoWoodyrsquo Wood was to prove the hero after Kruger, a -year-old black Labrador, went missing on Sunday, November , at about pm.Kruger was on his regular evening walk with owner Janette Murray, , of North Berwickrsquos Rhodes Park, next to the former East Lothian Council depot at Lime Grove.But after going to investigate a scent, he did notwhen called.Janettersquos daughter, -year-old Donna Denton, of the townrsquos Couper Avenue, told the Courier: ldquoHe is a rehomed dog, my mum got him when he was three.ldquoHe is quite timid but very, very friendly and doesnrsquot growl or bark at people ndash I have two kids and hersquos great with them.ldquoIf he does wander off he comes back as soon as he canrsquot see you, he always stays very close.ldquoWe now know the reason he didnrsquot come back this time. The lady from search and rescue said dogs donrsquot bark for help, only when they feel threatened.Kruger was found two days later by Bay City Rollers star Wood at about .am on Tuesday ndash the musician, who was on holiday in North Berwick, was one of  looking for the missing dog.He later posted on Facebook to say ldquothanks for the lovely messages and praising everyone who ldquosearched relentlessly.ldquoWell done everyone ndash we got lucky! he added.The terried dog was eventually found just metres from where he went missing.People all over North Berwick had helped in the search, not realising that Kruger was so close by.One man checked every bunker on the  holes at nearby Glen Golf Club ndashcounting  in total.Kruger gained access to the derelict Lime Grove site through a broken fence.Donna, a childminder and registered nurse, said: ldquoThe hole he fell down was no bigger than  centimetres by  centimetres, he couldnrsquot even lie down in it and was sitting up the whole time he was down there. We couldnrsquot even get our feet in there to help lt him out.ldquoWe phoned the fire brigade as we didnrsquot know what to do but my husband ended up putting a hoist around him and, with another manrsquos help, lting Kruger out with brute force.And she added: ldquoThe area he was found in is such a state and an absolute junkyard ndash therersquos broken bins and slabs everywhere, graffiti etc. It is not safe and is not secure.During the search, Donna contacted the police, SSPCA, search and rescue, the council and Edinburgh Dog and Cat Home, though she said she ldquocouldnrsquot get through to the dog warden at the council.After being rescued and wrapped up in blankets, Kruger was then sent to the vets for a check-up.Donna added: ldquoA man from the council had keys to the gate at the site and let me reverse my car in so I could put Kruger in the back.ldquo[Kruger] was really stf, so we had to carry him into the car and into the vets.ldquoHe was put on some fluids but my mum was able to get him home later that night luckily he wasnrsquot hurt.An appeal to find Kruger posted on social media attracted plenty of attention, something Donna was not expecting.She was full of praise for everyone who helped out, saying: ldquoEveryone was amazing. I had people I didnrsquot know come up to me at the school gates saying they were going to look for Kruger. We were just so lucky it was two mild nights when he was down there.ldquoMy mum will be  next year but was out all day trying to look for him, she didnrsquot want to stop or turn back. She was determined to find him.Since the incident, the hole has been covered with a slab, but the fence still remains damaged.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoIf anyone is aware of an uncovered manhole then itrsquos recommended that they report the exact location to the council, who will investigate further to make it safe.ldquoThis can be done online or via our out of hours number:  .

title: new-musselburgh-bar-gets-go-ahead
story: The Musselburgh Bar and Kitchen, formerly the Mexican restaurant Habaneros on High Street, was granted a iation of premises licence by East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board last week.Owner Star Pubs  Bars had applied for: extension of opening hours from midnight to am on a Thursday use of premises for clubs and group meetings an outdoor drinking area changes both internally to the building to re-position bar and seating areas and extension of the rear drinking smoking area outside.A number of objections centred around concerns of possible noise disturbance and smoke from the outdoor area.The board heard that the outdoor smoking area would be moved from its present location away from neighbouring properties and that this area would also be covered by CCTV.Members of the licensing board agreed to grant permission with conditions. They included that children and young people under  could only be on the premises after pmthey were having a meal or attending a private, pre-arranged , and that CCTV was operational both within and outside the building.In addition, the beer garden would close at pm and an entertainment licence was not granted so no recorded or live music could be played outside.The new bar had previously received planning permission.A spokesperson for Star Pubs  Bars said the premises would be turned into ldquoa modern premium bar.She said it was hoped that a new licensee would take on the venture, which would offer food throughout the day and alfresco dining.She said the proposed investment followed another recent refurbishment project involving Star Pubs  Bars at The Seaglass Inn, Port Seton, previously the Wemyss Hotel.

title: general-election-candidates-lock-horns-hustings
story: The event ndash at St Andrew Blackadder Church ndash saw the candidates answering questions submitted by the public ahead of the election next Thursday.Organised by North Berwick and District Association of Churches, it was chaired by Keith Stewart QC.Labourrsquos Martin Whitfield began by saying that serving as MP for the last two years had been a pleasure and a privilege.He also said: ldquoI am the only pro-Union person sitting on this  that can win here, which Conservative candidate Craig Hoy was quick to disagree with.David Sisson, UKIP, used a cookie jar analogy to make his partyrsquos position on Brexit clear saying: ldquoThe cookies belong to us. Itrsquos time we get them back and we can work out how we split them up once we have them back.Answering a question on how to tackle climate change Robert OrsquoRiordan, Liberal Democrats, said: ldquoI think that one of the best ways is to stay within the EU.The SNPrsquos candidate Kenny MacAskill said the country needed to disinvest in fossil fuels.The next question asked candidatesthey thought there ought to be a  per cent majority threshold on referendums.Mr MacAskill said he didnrsquot, adding: ldquoPeople werenrsquot voting for a no deal Brexit, that was never put forward. I agree that the majority prevails, but I think we have to realise thatyou win by one the winner canrsquot have all.Mr Hoy said he would agree there should be a threshold in future elections.He added: ldquoI understand why Kenny doesnrsquot support it because the SNP can barely secure  per cent, never mind  per cent, for independence.Candidates were then asked why they should be trusted by the public.Mr Sisson took this opportunity to point out that he wasnrsquot a politician and he was standing because he felt it was the right thing to do.Mr Whitfield suggested constituents believe those who did what they said they would do, adding: ldquoI think the Government breaking the law and having to be told by the Supreme Court that they have broken the law severely undermines the trust in politicians.Next, with Russia raised as a potential threat, candidates were asked about defence spending.MacAskill thought the defence budget should not change, saying: ldquoThe dficulty that faces our military is that everything is being put into nuclear weapons and Trident. I do not believe in Trident, I do not believe in nuclear weapons.Mr Sisson questioned the British Armyrsquos future as ldquoBritish defence more and more seems to be integrated into European forces.Mr Hoy said the Conservatives would increase expenditure on defence by . per cent above the rate of inflation. He added: ldquoTrident makes us safer.Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThere is a commitment from a Labour government to maintain its position in NATO and the two per cent. There is a commitment to renew Trident.Mr OrsquoRiordan also said he would maintain the two per cent GDP target, adding: ldquoIrsquom not sure of the nature of the Russian threat ndash I think it is much more to do with cyberspace and the threat to our democracy.ldquoAs we know, Boris Johnson has a dossier on his desk which he hasnrsquot released that talks about Russian intervention in the European referendum and in the European elections.Question then focused on healing the isions from Brexit, Islamophobia, and anti-Semitism in politics.Mr Hoy said he thought ldquothe issue of accountability in politics is extremely important, adding that, on comments made by Boris Johnson mocking Muslim womenrsquos appearance, he thought ldquothe Prime Minister should be held to the same account for any particular phrases that he uses but ldquothat would be for him to comment on.Mr Whitfield said he believed the Labour Party should apologise to the Jewish community for its handling of complaints of anti-Semitism in the party.He added: ldquoWith regard to what happens to bring society together widely, I think a referendum or confirmatory vote would allow people to discuss and debate and then to express their feelings through ballot box.Mr MacAskill called for better education and more enforcement, adding: ldquoYou cannot just whip up hatred and say what you like.Lastly, the candidates were asked what three things they had done for East Lothian.Mr Hoy mentioned implementing the Change and Check breast cancer campaign, voting for East Lothian Councilrsquos emergency climate change declaration, and working with police to tackle anti-social behaviour and drug use in the county.Mr Whitfield highlighted helping people with Universal Credit payments, taking county art therapy charity The Teapot Trust to Westminster and, in his previous job as a primary school teacher, teaching children in East Lothian who he had now seen getting jobs and apprenticeships.Mr OrsquoRiordan listed his involvement in setting up the hustings and working with church groups, working towards achieving the Drem-Gullane path, and convening East Lothian Liberal Democrats.Mr MacAskill cited, in his time as Justice Secretary, establishing the CashBack for Communities scheme, helping implement minimum alcohol pricing, and reducing youth offending.Mr Sisson answered by describing his work as an electrician for the council, choosing to stand as an MP, and his involvement with Musselburgh Amateur Musical Association.When asked to sing the last line of his answer by title: bid-build-new-hotel-replace-gullanes-mallard
story: Gullanersquos The Mallard Hotel has been run by the same family for more than half a century but new plans reveal a dramatic change for the East Links Road venue.Information boards were on display in the hotel last Thursday afternoon before a presentation was given to the villagersquos community council.Currently, the hotel is made up of  bedrooms, with a bar, bistro and garden room open to the public.However, the proposed new hotel ndash which would be built over three floors ndash would include  bedrooms, as well as a restaurant, lounge and spa facilities.Structured House Group is behind the plans, with a formal planning application expected to be with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department before the end of the year.Hotel owners Cameron and Susan Law intend to step down from the business, which has been in the family for  years,the proposals are given the green light.Susan, who is also chairman of Muirfield Riding Therapy, which offers free horse-riding for people with disabilities, stressed that The Mallard Hotel remained open for business as usual and would continue to be so for the foreseeable future.She told the Courier: ldquoI think, initially, I was quite shocked that it was going to be knocked down but in retrospect it is the best thing really.ldquoObviously, we will be sad to see it go but we will take The Mallard Hotel with us is how I am thinking now. It is very dear to us.About  people attended the public exhibition in the hotel and Tony Thomas, representing the developers, was pleased with how the six-hour drop-in event had gone.He said: ldquoIt was overwhelmingly positive ndash mainly because it is not housing [being proposed].ldquoThe vast majority of people really, really like the design. The only slight hiccup was two or three immediate neighbours were concerned over parking so we will look at that. If there is not enough parking, it spills out onto the street.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, was at the presentation and the meeting afterwards.He said there were concerns about the proposals and noted residentsrsquo worries about parking and traffic generated by the new hotel.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoThe plans were well presented.ldquoWhat they are proposing is a fine installation and it looks as though it would be a good, upmarket, modern hotel with good facilities.ldquoThere is considerable concern in the community about the problems likely to arise from car parking.ldquoThat was the big issue in the discussions at the community council meeting.ldquoThere were a lot of people indicating signicant concern on that point. It is quite a heavily built-up residential area and already the parking is under pressure from residents.ldquoI would say the new hotel has signicantly more rooms than the present one. It is also supposedly going to have an upmarket restaurant, which will attract evening customers.
